theory: Luffy's bones are hollow like a bird's skeleton, which would explain how he can inflate them with air without breaking them. Since Luffy can stretch and still stand tall, his bones must have properties of both rubber and bone, combining the hardness of bone with the elasticity of rubber.
author: One Piece Fandom Community
supportingEvidence: Luffy can inflate his bones without them breaking
The skeleton fully connects all joints allowing air redistribution
Luffy maintains structural integrity despite bone inflation
counterEvidence: Never explicitly stated in canon that bones are hollow
Luffy's body has shown normal bone density in other contexts

theory: The shrinking side effect of Gear Third is proportional to how much the user inflates and how long they maintain it, suggesting it's an energy conservation mechanic where the body must compensate for the temporary enlargement by temporarily shrinking.
author: One Piece Community Discussions
supportingEvidence: Episode 305 shows Luffy shrinking after using Gear Third
The duration of shrinking appears connected to usage time
This mechanic prevents Gear Third from being overpowered
counterEvidence: After the timeskip, Luffy overcomes this side effect entirely
The exact mechanics are never fully explained

theory: Gear Third's power being comparable to giants foreshadows that Luffy will eventually face or befriend giants, and that the technique was specifically developed by Luffy thinking about how to match giant-level strength to overcome powerful enemies.
author: CBR Analysis
supportingEvidence: Luffy explicitly states his attacks have the power of giants
Later arcs feature significant giant characters and locations
Luffy's creative problem-solving often draws from his experiences
counterEvidence: Luffy had already encountered giants before (Little Garden arc)
The connection may be coincidental rather than intentional foreshadowing
